title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement amices.org. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Get started
text: ggmice package provides visualizations evaluation incomplete data, mice imputation model arguments, multiply imputed data sets (mice::mids objects). functions ggmice adhere ‘grammar graphics’ philosophy, popularized ggplot2 package. , ggmice enhances imputation workflows provides plotting objects easily extended manipulated individual ‘imputer’. vignette gives overview different plotting function ggmice. core function, ggmice(), ggplot2::ggplot() wrapper function handles missing imputed values. vignette, ’ll learn create interpret ggmice visualizations. Experienced mice users may already familiar lattice style plotting functions mice. ‘old friends’ mice::bwplot() can re-created ggmice() function, see Old friends vignette advice.

title: Get started
text: can install latest ggmice release CRAN : development version ggmice package can installed GitHub : installing ggmice, can load package R workspace. highly recommended load mice ggplot2 packages well. vignette assumes three packages loaded: use mice::boys data illustrations. incomplete dataset (\(n = 748\)) cross-sectional data \(9\) growth-related variables. load incomplete data : purpose vignette, impute incomplete variables \(m = 3\) times predictive mean matching imputation method. Imputations generated : now necessary packages, incomplete dataset (dat), mice::mids object (imp) loaded workspace.
code: install.packages("ggmice") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("amices/ggmice") library(mice)  library(ggplot2) library(ggmice) dat <- boys imp <- mice(dat, m = 3, method = "pmm")

title: Get started
text: core function ggmice package ggmice(). function mimics ggplot2 function ggplot() works: take data argument mapping argument, return object class ggplot. Using ggmice() looks equivalent ggplot() call: main difference two functions ggmice() actually wrapper around ggplot(), including pre-processing steps incomplete imputed data. internal processing ggmice(), mapping argument required ggmice() call. contrast aesthetic mapping ggplot(), may also provided subsequent plotting layers. creating ggplot object, desired plotting layers may added (e.g., family ggplot2::geom_* functions), adjusted (e.g., ggplot2::labs() function). makes ggmice() versatile plotting function incomplete /imputed data. object supplied data argument ggmice() incomplete dataset class data.frame, imputation object class mice::mids. Depending one provided, resulting visualization either differentiate observed missing data, observed imputed data. convention, observed data plotted blue missing imputed data plotted red. mapping argument ggmice() empty. x y mapping () supplied ggmice() function. aesthetic mapping can provided ggplot2 function aes() (equivalents). mapping may provided , except colour, already used display observed versus missing imputed data.
code: ggplot(dat, aes(age, bmi)) ggmice(dat, aes(age, bmi))

title: Get started
text: object supplied data argument ggmice() data.frame, visualization contain observed data blue missing data red. Since missing data points definition unobserved, values plotted. can plot sets variable pairs. missing values one variable can displayed top axis . provides visual cue missing data distinct observed values, still displays observed value variable. example, variable age completely observed, missing entries bmi. can create scatter plot two variables :  age cases missing bmi plotted top horizontal axis. contrast regular ggplot() call arguments, leave cases missing bmi. , ggmice() loose less information, may even gain valuable insight missingness data. Another example ggmice() action incomplete data one variables categorical. incomplete continuous variable bmi plotted incomplete categorical variable reg :  , missing values plotted top axes. Cases observed bmi missing reg plotted top vertical axis. Cases observed reg missing bmi plotted top horizontal axis. cases neither observed, otherwise plotted intersection two axes. ‘grammar graphics’ makes easy adjust plots programmatically. example, interested differences growth data city regions. Add facets based clustering variable :  , alternatively, convert plotted values variable hgt centimeters inches variable wgt kilograms pounds :
code: ggmice(dat, aes(age, bmi)) +   geom_point() ggmice(dat, aes(reg, bmi)) +   geom_point() ggmice(dat, aes(wgt, hgt)) +   geom_point() +   facet_wrap(~ reg == "city", labeller = label_both) ggmice(dat, aes(wgt * 2.20, hgt / 2.54)) +   geom_point() +   labs(x = "Weight (lbs)", y = "Height (in)")

title: Get started
text: data argument ggmice() provided mice::mids object, resulting plot contain observed data blue imputed data red. many possible visualizations imputed data, four explicitly defined mice package. can re-created ggmice() function (see Old friends vignette). ggmice() can even . example, create scatter plots ones , now imputed data:     figures show observed data points blue, plus three imputed values red missing entry. also possible use imputation number mapping variable plot. example, can create stripplot observed imputed data imputation number .imp horizontal axis:  major advantage ggmice() equivalent function mice::stripplot() ggmice allows us add subsequent plotting layes, boxplot overlay:  re-create mice plot ggmice, see Old friends vignette.
code: ggmice(imp, aes(age, bmi)) +   geom_point() ggmice(imp, aes(reg, bmi)) +   geom_point() ggmice(imp, aes(wgt, hgt)) +   geom_point() +   facet_wrap(~ reg == "city", labeller = label_both) ggmice(imp, aes(wgt * 2.20, hgt / 2.54)) +   geom_point() +   labs(x = "Weight (lbs)", y = "Height (in)") ggmice(imp, aes(x = .imp, y = bmi)) +   geom_jitter(height = 0, width = 0.25) +   labs(x = "Imputation number") ggmice(imp, aes(x = .imp, y = bmi)) +    geom_jitter(height = 0, width = 0.25) +   geom_boxplot(width = 0.5, size = 1, alpha = 0.75, outlier.shape = NA) +   labs(x = "Imputation number")

title: Get started
text: ggmice package contains additional plotting functions explore incomplete data evaluate convergence imputation algorithm. presented order typical imputation workflow, missingness first investigated using missing data pattern influx-outflux plot, imputation models built based relations variables, finally imputations inspected visually check non-convergence.

title: Get started
text: plot_pattern() function displays missing data pattern incomplete dataset. argument data (incomplete dataset) required, argument square optional determines whether missing data pattern square rectangular tiles, optional argument rotate changes angle variable names 90 degrees requested.
code: # create missing data pattern plot plot_pattern(dat) # specify optional arguments   plot_pattern(dat, square = TRUE, rotate = TRUE)

title: Get started
text: plot_flux() function produces influx-outflux plot. influx variable quantifies well missing data connect observed data variables. outflux variable quantifies well observed data connect missing data variables. general, higher influx outflux values preferred building imputation models. plotting function requires incomplete dataset (argument data), takes optional arguments adjust legend axis labels.
code: # create influx-outflux plot plot_flux(dat) # specify optional arguments   plot_flux(   dat,    label = FALSE,    caption = FALSE )

title: Get started
text: function plot_corr() can used investigate relations variables, development imputation models. one arguments (data, incomplete dataset) required, arguments optional.
code: # create correlation plot plot_corr(dat) # specify optional arguments   plot_corr(   dat,   vrb = c("hgt", "wgt", "bmi"),   label = TRUE,   square = FALSE,   diagonal = TRUE )

title: Get started
text: function plot_pred() displays mice predictor matrices. predictor matrix typically created using mice::make.predictorMatrix(), mice::quickpred(), using default mice::mice() extracting predictorMatrix resulting mids object. plot_pred() function requires predictor matrix (data argument), arguments can provided .
code: # create predictor matrix pred <- quickpred(dat)  # create predictor matrix plot plot_pred(pred) # specify optional arguments   plot_pred(   pred,    label = FALSE,    square = FALSE )

title: Get started
text: function plot_trace() plots trace lines MICE algorithm convergence evaluation. required argument data (supply mice::mids object). optional argument vrb defaults "", display traceplots variables.
code: # create traceplot for one variable plot_trace(imp, "bmi")

title: Get started

[45] grid_4.2.0        cli_3.3.0         tools_4.2.0       magrittr_2.0.3    #> [49] sass_0.4.1        tibble_3.1.7      crayon_1.5.1      tidyr_1.2.0       #> [53] pkgconfig_2.0.3   ellipsis_0.3.2 what: Create the ggmice equivalent of mice plots
title: Old friends
text: re-create output plotting functions mice ggmice. alphabetical order mice functions. First load ggmice package, incomplete data mice::mids object workspace.
code: # load packages library(ggmice) # load incomplete dataset  dat <- mice::boys # generate imputations imp <- mice::mice(dat, method = "pmm", printFlag = FALSE)

title: Old friends
text: Box--whisker plot observed imputed data.
code: # original plot mice::bwplot(imp, bmi ~ .imp) # ggmice equivalent ggmice(imp, ggplot2::aes(x = .imp, y = bmi)) +       ggplot2::geom_boxplot() +       ggplot2::labs(x = "Imputation number") # extended reproduction with ggmice ggmice(imp, ggplot2::aes(x = .imp, y = bmi)) +   ggplot2::stat_boxplot(geom = 'errorbar', linetype = "dashed") +   ggplot2::geom_boxplot(outlier.colour = "grey", outlier.shape = 1) +   ggplot2::labs(x = "Imputation number") +   ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "none")

title: Old friends
text: Density plot observed imputed data.
code: # original plot mice::densityplot(imp, ~bmi) # ggmice equivalent ggmice(imp, ggplot2::aes(x = bmi, group = .imp)) +       ggplot2::geom_density() # extended reproduction with ggmice ggmice(imp, ggplot2::aes(x = bmi, group = .imp, size = .where)) +   ggplot2::geom_density() +   ggplot2::scale_size_manual(values = c("observed" = 1, "imputed" = 0.5),                              guide = "none") +   ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "none")

title: Old friends
text: Influx outflux plot multivariate missing data patterns.
code: # original plot mice::fluxplot(dat) # ggmice equivalent plot_flux(dat)

title: Old friends
text: Missing data pattern plot.
code: # original plot md <- mice::md.pattern(dat) # ggmice equivalent plot_pattern(dat) # extended reproduction with ggmice plot_pattern(dat, square = TRUE) +   ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "none",                  axis.title = ggplot2::element_blank(),                  axis.title.x.top = ggplot2::element_blank(),                  axis.title.y.right = ggplot2::element_blank())

title: Old friends
text: Plot trace lines MICE algorithm.
code: # original plot plot(imp, bmi ~ .it | .ms) # ggmice equivalent plot_trace(imp, "bmi")

title: Old friends
text: Stripplot observed imputed data.
code: # original plot mice::stripplot(imp, bmi ~ .imp) # ggmice equivalent ggmice(imp, ggplot2::aes(x = .imp, y = bmi)) +   ggplot2::geom_jitter(width = 0.25) +   ggplot2::labs(x = "Imputation number") # extended reproduction with ggmice (not recommended) ggmice(imp, ggplot2::aes(x = .imp, y = bmi)) +   ggplot2::geom_jitter(     shape = 1,     width = 0.1,     na.rm = TRUE,     data = data.frame(       bmi = dat$bmi,       .imp = factor(rep(1:imp$m, each = nrow(dat))),       .where = "observed"     )   ) +   ggplot2::geom_jitter(shape = 1, width = 0.1) +   ggplot2::labs(x = "Imputation number") +   ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "none")

title: Old friends
text: Scatterplot observed imputed data.
code: # original plot mice::xyplot(imp, bmi ~ age) # ggmice equivalent ggmice(imp, ggplot2::aes(age, bmi)) +   ggplot2::geom_point() # extended reproduction with ggmice ggmice(imp, ggplot2::aes(age, bmi)) +   ggplot2::geom_point(size = 2, shape = 1) +   ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "none")

title: Old friends

title: Authors and Citation
text: Hanne Oberman. Author, maintainer. Utrecht University. Funder. University Medical Centre Utrecht. Funder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Oberman H (2022). ggmice: Visualizations 'mice' 'ggplot2'. https://github.com/amices/ggmice, https://amices.org/, https://amices.org/ggmice/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {ggmice: Visualizations for 'mice' with 'ggplot2'},   author = {Hanne Oberman},   year = {2022},   note = {https://github.com/amices/ggmice, https://amices.org/, https://amices.org/ggmice/}, }

title: Visualizations for mice with ggplot2
text: Enhance mice imputation workflow visualizations incomplete /imputed data. ggmice functions produce ggplot objects may easily manipulated extended. Use ggmice inspect missing data, develop imputation models, evaluate algorithmic convergence, compare observed versus imputed data.

title: Visualizations for mice with ggplot2
text: can install latest ggmice release CRAN : Alternatively, install development version ggmice GitHub :
code: install.packages("ggmice") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("amices/ggmice")

title: Visualizations for mice with ggplot2
text: Inspect missing data incomplete dataset subsequently evaluate imputed data points observed data. See Get started vignette overview functionalities. Example data mice.
code: # load packages library(ggplot2) library(mice) library(ggmice) # load some data dat <- boys # visualize the incomplete data ggmice(dat, aes(age, bmi)) + geom_point() # impute the incomplete data imp <- mice(dat, m = 1, printFlag = FALSE) # visualize the imputed data ggmice(imp, aes(age, bmi)) + geom_point()

title: Visualizations for mice with ggplot2
text: ggmice package developed guidance feedback Gerko Vink, Stef van Buuren, Thomas Debray, Valentijn de Jong, Johanna Muñoz, Thom Volker, Mingyang Cai Anaïs Fopma. ggmice hex based designs ggplot2 hex mice hex (Jaden Walters). project received funding European Union’s Horizon 2020 research innovation programme ReCoDID grant agreement 825746.

title: Visualizations for mice with ggplot2
text: invited join improvement development ggmice. Please note project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: Box-and-whisker plot of observed and imputed data — bwplot
code: imp <- mice::mice(mice::nhanes, maxit = 1, printFlag = FALSE) bwplot(imp) #> Hint: Did you know, an equivalent figure can be created with `ggmice()`? #> For example, to plot a variable named 'my_vrb' from a mids object called 'my_mids', run:  #>  #>     ggmice(my_mids, ggplot2::aes(x = .imp, y = my_vrb)) + #>     ggplot2::geom_boxplot()  #>  #> See amices.org/ggmice for more info.

title: Plot correlations between (incomplete) variables — plot_corr
text: data dataset class data.frame, tibble, matrix. vrb String vector variable name(s), default "". label Logical indicating whether correlation values displayed. square Logical indicating whether plot tiles squares. diagonal Logical indicating whether correlation variable displayed. rotate Logical indicating whether variable name labels rotated 90 degrees.
